subNodes.conversationText: root

<FirstName> lost <his/her> senses. Sight, first, then all the others. <He/She> had no one way of knowing if <his/her> companions were nearby. Though conscious, nothing told <him/her> if <he/she> was reaching out when <he/she> tried to reach out. Nothing told <him/her> if <he/she> was standing or falling.
[Continue.]

Then sense came back all at once.

Many hands. Bodies pressing in on him from all sides. A cavernous room with wood paneling and tall windows obscured by velvet curtains. And voices, so many voices... A complete cacophony of accusation, contempt, and glee; Pharaoh cawing; and, behind it all, the voice of the ocean -- the waves of the Secret Sea somewhere nearby.
[Continue.]

The Congress of Moths had grabbed <his/her> robes and were tugging <him/her> in different directions. One of the many arguments <he/she> heard had to do with where they ought to take <him/her>. Some said the cellar, some said the attic. Some said they should throw <him/her> in the Secret Sea, and some kept referring to a place called the Chamber.

<He/She> saw Knott trying to shake the beings off, but a parliamentarian clambered on top of him and threw a sack over his head. Another caught Pharaoh in a net of golden mesh.
[Continue.]

"I have seniority here," said a censor in a booming voice. The mob quieted down but still clung to <FirstName>. "I'll decide where <he/she> goes." He turned to <FirstName>.

"Why are you here, young witch? Mortals do not usually come before us."
"The kami told me to seek you out. You know who killed Nnenne."
The throng of beings started whispering among themselves.
[Continue.]
"If I may, Censor," said a magistrate. "Now is not the time for questions. The door only admits petitioners; ergo, the witch is a petitioner. Petitioners must seek relief in the Chamber."
"What kind of relief can I expect?"
"The Congress has many remedies for many ills. Dismemberment is common, but other means of satisfying petitioners' demands are sometimes employed."
[Continue.]
"What is this Chamber?"
The Congress exploded in scornful laughter and started chattering about the young witch's amusing ignorance.
[Continue.]
"Enough. Serjeants, bind the witch. We will escort <him/her> to the Chamber."
[Continue.]

The serjeants did as they were told. But some disagreed with this plan -- the ones who had wanted to throw <him/her> in the sea --, and they had to be beaten before they could make their way to the Chamber.
[Continue.]

They made very slow progress. It was hard for the censor to keep order. Gleeful jostling, more beatings, and some confusion about the best way to reach the Chamber made the journey last an hour by the young witch's estimation.

The architecture of the place was baffling and unsystematic.They passed from antechamber to vestibule, from vestibule to antechamber. Some rooms were grand, others small. Decoration was everywhere and likewise a muddle -- pornographic mosaics, a realistic oil painting of unicorns pulling a plow, a four-foot marble statue of a squirrel, a canopic jar filled with strawberry candies, and many yet stranger things.
[Continue.]

"We've reached the Chamber doors," said the censor finally. The "doors" the censor mentioned were just one door -- a small plank affair with a crescent moon on it, like that of an outhouse. He continued: "The House is in session, so we will have to wait out here until they're ready to hear from you."

The mob quieted down. Some apparently lost interest and drifted out of the room. The serjeants demonstrated surprising humanity and loosened the cords they had tied around the young witch's wrists and liberated Knott and Pharaoh, too.
[Continue.]

More time passed. Another ten minutes, then another twenty, then an hour. The young witch surmised that time passed differently here than in the world above -- <he/she> hoped that was the case, anyway. The witches' sabbath was almost at hand. <He/She> listened to the waves pounding on and on. It was impossible to tell which direction the ocean lay.

The censor yawned.
<FirstName> waited, leaning against the marble wall.

The wall moved, and <FirstName> stumbled backward. The Congress screamed in dismay. What had appeared to be marble was a huge painted board. Even the windows and curtains were painted. A gust of wind smelling of saltwater blew into the room. Panicking, an impromptu crew set about righting the wall.

The censor told <him/her> to move away from it and scolded <him/her>.
[Continue.]

"If you're fidgety, why don't you brush up on procedural rules? There are some books over there," he said, pointing to a table that <FirstName> hadn't noticed before. It was piled high with musty-looking tomes.
<FirstName> doubted that any sort of preparation would help, so <he/she> declined.
Eventually the door opened, and an usher stepped out -- followed by another, and then another. Soon seven ushers stood in the room, flanking the way to the Chamber door.
[Continue.]
"Another fight. House procedures."
[End.]
<FirstName> perused the books.

They had unprepossessing titles like Rules of (Dis)order: Ludojuridical Rules, Ludonarrative Dissonances and The Parliamentary Basics Primer, Volume 3.5 (the other volumes were missing). The authors had silly names like Lawrence Shelflife and Clive Banderstamper. could find no instructions that seemed relevant.
[Continue.]
Eventually the door opened, and an usher stepped out -- followed by another, and then another. Soon seven ushers stood in the room, flanking the way to the Chamber door.
<FirstName> sat down in a nearby chair.
A terrific braying came from <FirstName>'s seat, which had transformed into a donkey. The Congress laughed as <FirstName> clung to the beast's neck.
[Continue.]
"See that, see that?" A page pointed to the witch and the donkey. He started counting: "One...two...three!"
[Continue.]
"Explain," demanded the censor.
[Continue.]

The page counted on his fingers and pointed as he named the objects referred to: 

"ONE. One witch. Also one donkey. TWO. Two drudges. The donkey is a drudge, and the witch is also a drudge. THREE. Three asses. The first ass is the donkey. The second ass is the witch, for this witch is a foolish ass. The third ass belongs to the witch and sits upon the first."
[Continue.]
"Your assessment neglects the donkey's ass."
[Continue.]
"Your father should have done the same."
[Continue.]

The throng laughed. The censor, annoyed, took out a poniard and stabbed the page through the heart. The crowd stopped laughing. Then the censor turned to the young witch, helping <him/her> off the donkey.
[Continue.]
The young witch kept quiet.
"Enough. Serjeants, bind the witch. We will escort <him/her> to the Chamber."
"I just happened to be passing by," said the young witch dryly.
"Tut tut. We get to make the jokes," said the censor.
[Continue.]
"If I may, Censor," said a magistrate. "Now is not the time for questions. The door only admits petitioners; ergo, the witch is a petitioner. Petitioners must seek relief in the Chamber."
"The door opened for me. I came in."
"Answers questions very evasively," said a redcap whom <FirstName> hadn't noticed before. She was taking notes in a little book. "Sure sign of guilt."
[Continue.]
